newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Romania's Banc Post seen second bank to go private.
newsitem.headline: Romania's Banc Post seen second bank to go private.

text.p: Romania's state-owned Banc Post SA is likely to be the second commercial bank to go private under government reforms, the World Bank resident representative in Bucharest said on Thursday.
"It was officially agreed that Banc Post is the second to be privatised," Francois Ettori told Reuters in an interview.
Banc Post was launched in 1992 and conducts savings operations for individuals through post offices across Romania. Its financial results for 1996 and 1995 were not available.
Bank privatisation is one of the main goals of the Romanian government's reforms and a plank to win support from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
Earlier this year, Romania passed a selloff bill for its six state-run banks and pledged to privatise at least one bank, Banca Romana pentru Dezvoltare SA (BRD) development bank, by the end of 1997.
Ettori said Romania should privatise two banks in order to draw the final $100 million tranche of a World Bank Financial and Enterprise Adjustment Loan (FESAL).
"This does not exclude that they might have a third bank privatised this year," Ettori said.
Farm lender Banca Agricola SA is seen the next potential bank to be privatised.

On Tuesday, the World Bank approved a $550 million loan poackage for Romania to underpin farm reforms, social security and road upgrading. A second tranche of $80 million of the $280 million FESAL facility for industry restructuring should be released by the end of the week.
Romania drew a $100 million FESAL tranche last year before the Bank suspended credits over discontent with reforms conducted by the former leftist administration ousted in last November's elections.
